bibl.title: Letter from James P. Leake to Philip Showalter Hench, December 10, 1946

div1.p: Leake feels that Hench's book offers an opportunity to clarify conflicting claims concerning the yellow fever experiments. Leake is especially interested in Carter's role. He has written to Carter's son and will let Hench know when he receives a reply.

div1.head: Letter from James P. Leake to Philip Showalter Hench, December 10, 1946
div1.opener:
FEDERAL SECURITY AGENCY
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF HEALTH
BETHESDA, MARYLAND
December 10, 1946
DIVISION OF INFECTIOUS DISEASES
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your interesting letter of the 3rd has just arrived and doubtless
the reprint will soon be here. Thank you for both. It has occurred
to me that the writing of your book would be a good occasion to try
and straighten out the conflicting claims or statements that have been
made - you doubtless encountered many Cuban enthusiasts who think
Finlay's part has been minimized; not all have been as ungentlemanly
to Agramonte as Henry Long was to his widow. My own concern was
Dr. Henry R. Carter's friendship with Walter Reed and Carter's desire
that his own large share in the discovery should not detract from the
memory and fame of Walter Reed. I have written to Carter's son, and
on hearing from him will let you know.
What do you think of the above?
div1.closer:
Sincerely, James P. Leake
Med. Dir. (Retired)
U.S.P.H.S. JPL/msb
